title: Mysterious inventor charges £26,000 to 'bring rain' to drought stricken farms
text:

An inventor is charging drought stricken farmers £26,000 to unleash mysterious and controversial technology he claims makes it rain.

For the past two decades David Miles has been bringing technology he has argued changes the weather onto the market.

Through his most recent company Miles Research, the pioneer is offering his services to farmers in Victoria, Australia.

In return for $50,000AU (£26,614), Mr Miles provides farmers with three-month long rain contracts.

The innovator refuses to reveal how his technology works for fear, he says, it would be stolen by other companies or "weaponised" by the government.

The company's website does explain that Mr Miles realised in the 1990s that he could "incrementally influence weather patterns using a variant of the Einstein - Rosen Bridge hypothesised in the 1930's."

(Image: Getty Images)

By creating a "bridge between the present in the physical space-time continuum" and a "near future event" - namely rain - Mr Miles says he can cause droplets to fall.

The ambitious inventor claims he can look ten days into the future using "meteorological forecast data and high-resolution supercomputing" and "intelligently" apply a small amount of energy to adjust the path of the weather.

Through a domino like effect, this small change is amplified as the course of time is reverse, Mr Miles claims, causing great rain clouds to form.

The rain man has suggested he has had success through the complicated scheme, with a group of farmers in Wimmera enjoying a drought busting dousing of rain.

One of them told ABC Radio how happy they were with the service, which sees customers charged depending on how much precipitation is achieved.

“I think the evidence is out there, you look at the forecast what’s meant to come and all of a sudden it increases dramatically," the farmer told the radio station.

"You know that he’s behind it and I reckon I haven’t seen such good crops in this district ever, everywhere.”

Not everyone is so impressed by Mr Miles or convinced by his claims however.

Mick Keogh, Australian Competition and Consumer Commission deputy chairman, has accused the rain man of "preying on people's desperation".

University of Melbourne associate professor of physics Martin Sevior went further, accusing Mr Miles of "meaningless" pseudo science.

On a now deleted part of the company's website it is claimed the rain beckoning technology uses electromagnetic scalar waves.

The professor said: “Electromagnetic scalar waves don’t exist. There’s no such thing.

"He’s taken a few words and put them together and made them sound somewhat scientific but it’s meaningless.”

The made-up concept was brushed away as "legacy material" by Mr Miles in an interview with news.com.au.

When pushed on what the rain machine was, he likened it to a bank vault.

(Image: LUKAS COCH/EPA-EFE/REX/Shutterstock)

He went on to claim that Miles Research had not tried to patent the device for fear doing so would reveal how it is made.

"If we did that we’ll lose it, it will be taken up as a national security interest and it’ll then be weaponised," he said.

Despite sitting on what Mr Miles claims is technology capable of changing the weather, the company is not in good financial shape.

Its most recent accounts how Miles Research lost $70,000AU (£37,2390) in the last financial year and currently has debts of $780,000AU (£414,871).

Mr Miles blamed some of the cash issues on having to repay some farmers for not producing enough rain - the company's time having been taken up, he claimed, by a Consumer Affairs investigation.

Not one to be deterred, the weather man now wants to raise $10 million (£5.32 million) to build a “facility” to fully develop and prove the technology.

If Mr Miles can prove his detractors wrong he will prove a popular man.

The south-east of Australia is in the midst of a two year drought that is the worst in the area's history.
description: David Miles claims he can navigate the physical space-time continuum and bring future rain into the present
